column5: class_name
Comments or notes about the specimen (physical object) especially those that distinguish the specimen from similar materials in a collection
column6: Showpiece | Historically valuable | Extraordinary composition | Two generations of quartz
column7: See broader concept http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/occurrenceRemarks for additional usage notes

column5: The verbatim size of a specimen as originally described in primary source material
column6: 10 cm x 5 cm X 5 cm | largest diameter 16 cm | width 3 inches

column5: Maximum axial dimension of specimen measured in millimeters
The original reported verbatim mass includes original units of measurement
Mass of specimen measured in grams
Comments or notes about the mineral instance, especially those that distinguish the mineral from similar materials in a collection
column6: Pink fluorite on quartz | Lengenbachite on sugar-grained dolomite | Epitaxial growth on kyanite | Doubly terminated quartz crystals
column7: The scope of this term is strictly to a mineral within the context of the specimen. Specimen level descriptions belong in the related term, specimenDescription. Sibling concept to http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/occurrenceRemarks

column5: Maximum axial dimension of largest crystal measured in millimeters
List of secondary minerals associated with a mineral in a specimen
Observable crystal shapes of an assemblage of minerals
column7: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary

column5: A general term for describing the outward appearance of a mineral
column7: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary. For a given type of crystal, the habit may vary from locality to locality depending on environment of growth.

column5: Geometric shape of a crystal
column7: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary
column12: Alternate definition: A crystal form is a set of crystal faces that are related to each other by symmetry.

column5: Short description of any physically discernable twinning
column6: Dauphiné twinning/Dauphiné Law | Japan twinning/Japan Law | Brazil twinning/Brazil Law

column5: The intrinsic color of a mineral under natural light
column7: Here, color is caused by the absorption, or lack of absorption of different wavelengths of natural light by a particular mineral

column5: A brief description of textures formed by exsolution
column6: Ilmenite lamellae in olivine | Clinopyroxene lamellae along the (100) plane of orthopyroxene | Antiperthite exsolution.

column5: Type of breakages along a plane of weakness, especially those parallel to crystal faces
The reflection of light from the surface of a mineral, described by its quality and intensity
column7: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary

column5: Short description of any inclusions present within a mineral that includes the phase and physical characteristics
column6: Star-shaped rutile needles in quartz | Needles of tourmaline in quartz (blue quarz) | Fluid inclusions (liquid bubble and single crystal) in quartz
column12: Inclusions are defined as small foreign bodies (solid, liquid, or gas) within the physical bounds of a material commonly trapped during formation

column5: The type and nature of light emitted from the mineral upon receiving energy from an external source.
column6: Green fluorescence | Pink under short wave UV light
column7: Includes all types of luminescence including fluorescence (all wavelengths) and phosphorescence. Recommended best practice is to use nomenclature in part based on the source of energy, or the trigger for the luminescence.

column5: A description of any observed changes in the composition of a mineral brought about by physical or chemical processes related to changes in the physical or chemical environment.
column13: Definition adopted from the concepts under term sources
